questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD with the following Skin Manifestation of a Disease associated with Raynaud Phenomenon. What is the manifestation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Salt and Pepper Pigmentation

 

Option B: Salt and Pepper Pigmentation

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Systemic Sclerosis, and the skin manifestation shown is a Salt-and-Pepper Appearance.

 

  • An autoimmune condition with a complex pathogenesis, variable clinical presentations, and an unknown etiology is systemic sclerosis.
  • Significant disability and mortality are linked to it.
  • Almost all organs are impacted. Scleroderma, or thickened and indurated skin, is the defining characteristic of systemic sclerosis.
  • The typical white discoloration of the fingers brought on by vasospasm and the bluish discoloration of the fingertips are Raynaud phenomenon (first symptom) skin characteristics of systemic sclerosis.
  • The skin has a salt-and-pepper appearance when there is a loss of pigmentation, which is most noticeable on the upper back (as given in the question), chest, and scalp.
  • 4: 1 female predominance
  • Sclerodactyly and sclerosis extending proximal to the metacarpophalangeal joints with or without contractures.
  • Earliest cutaneous manifestations are non-pitting oedema and puffiness
  • Severe flexion contractures & Muscle weakness
  • Loss of fingertip pulp
  • Loss of sweat glands in distal extremities
  • Vasculopathic ulcers over the bony prominences
  • Expressionless facies, mat-like telangiectasias, microstomia, perioral furrowing, and a beak-like nose
  • Pruritus correlates with severity of cutaneous sclerosis
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease.
    • Interstitial lung disease is common in patients with Scl-70 antibodies
    • Nucleolar pattern of IF (some spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and it represents antibodies to RNA) is seen in systemic sclerosis.
    • Systemic sclerosis specific autoantibodies: anti-topoisomerase, anti-centromere and anti-RNA polymerase
    • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis or CREST syndrome: Anti-Centromere antibodies

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Poikiloderma is a skin disorder characterized by: (ATP)

 

  • Atrophy
  • Telangiectasias
  • Pigment abnormalities Hypo and hyper

 

It is seen in ionizing radiation-damaged skin and dermatomyositis.

 

Option C. Sometimes the colour of the hair can change to white in the amelanotic lesions of vitiligo. It is known as Leucotrichia.

 

Option D. Sharply demarcated depigmented macules are a hallmark of vitiligo. It results from the loss of melanocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

'Salt and pepper' pigmentation is a skin manifestation associated with systemic sclerosis, a condition commonly accompanied by Raynaud's phenomenon. This pattern includes both hyperpigmented and hypopigmented areas interspersed on the skin.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 56 Page No 56.1 – 56.23

choices.text: Dilated Capillary Loops in Nail Fold can be seen
Heliotrope Rash seen in this disease is associated with Anti-Mi-2 Antibodies.
Mechanic's Hands can be seen in this disease
Muscle Tenderness is common in this condition

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presented with Erythema & purplish tinge on upper eyelids & Erythema over shawl area as shown in the image below. She also had significantly elevated serum Creatinine phosphokinase levels. Identify the FALSE statement regarding this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Muscle Tenderness is common in this condition

 

Option D:

 

  • The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Dermatomyositis. Muscle tenderness is NOT COMMON in this disorder.
  • An autoimmune condition called Dermato-Myositis (DM) primarily affects the skin and skeletal muscles.

 

Explanation:

 

Option  A. Nail fold changes with periungual erythema with visible dilated capillary loops in the proximal nail fold.

 

Option B. Gottron's papule, heliotrope rash, and shawl sign are associated with anti-Mi2 antibodies.

 

Option C. Mechanic's hand: Roughening and cracking of the fingertip and side skin that results in scuffed, crooked lines that resemble those of a mechanic or manual labourer.

 

The following list includes several dermatomyositis symptoms:

 

  • Heliotrope rash around eyelids with a lilac hue.
  • Gottron's papules are violaceous, erythematous papules that can appear over the elbow, knee, dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints.
  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.
  • Shawl sign or V-sign: Fixed macular erythema spanning the shoulders and outer arms (Shawl distribution)

 

Proximal Myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Screening: Approximately 20 to 40% of patients have an underlying malignancy (eg, lung, ovarian, breast) and hence screening should be done at the time of diagnosis.

 

Diagnosis: Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Mechanic hand, Myositis, and ILD (Interstitial Lung Disease) are associated with anti-histidyl tRNA synthetase (anti-Jo-1) antibodies.

 

Prognosis: The presence of dysphagia points to a poorer prognosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In dermatomyositis, muscle tenderness is not a common finding; instead, patients typically present with muscle weakness, a heliotrope rash associated with anti-Mi-2 antibodies, mechanic's hands, and dilated capillary loops in the nail fold.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition, Chapter 53 Page no’s 53.5, 53.6 and 53.8

choices.text: Face and Scalp are the most frequently involved sites.
Non Scarring Alopecia is seen associated with Discoid Lupus Erythematosus.
Topical Steroids are the First Line treatment for Localised Lesions
Antimalarials can be used for treatment

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding Discoid Lupus Erythematosus except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non Scarring Alopecia is seen associated with Discoid Lupus Erythematosus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Non scarring alopecia is seen associated with Discoid Lupus Erythematosus.

  • A benign inflammatory skin condition called discoid lupus erythematosus usually affects the face and scalp, associated scarring alopecia (Option B) is seen.
  • It has distinct, red, scaly patches that can vary in size.
  • These patches heal with atrophy, scarring, and pigmentary changes.
  • The most common type of disease is the circumscribed or discoid form, which mainly affects the cheeks, nose bridge, ears, side of the neck, and scalp. (Option A)

 

The scalp-specific discoid lupus erythematosus with follicular plugging (Scarring alopecia) is depicted in the image below.

 

 

  • The skin lesions in discoid or chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus are well-defined erythematous patches with adherentscaling and peripheral hyperpigmentation.
  • The underside of the scale reveals horny plugs that have occupied dilated pilosebaceous canals when the scale is removed.
  • This sign is known as the "tin-tack" sign.
  • The first-line treatment for localized lesions is topical corticosteroids. (Option C)
  • Hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine are oral antimalarial drugs that can be used along with oral steroids and have a good response rate. (Option D)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Discoid lupus erythematosus (DLE) typically presents with scarring alopecia when it affects the scalp, distinguishing it from non-scarring forms of alopecia.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition, Chapter 51, Page no’s 51.4-51.10

questions.text: A young woman arrived at the OPD with the following Annular Polycyclic Rash. She also complained of Myalgia, Arthralgia, and Hair Loss. Her medical history was significant for sun aggravating her Skin complaints. A diagnosis of SCLE is considered. Which of the following is the most common cutaneous presentation of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non-Scarring Papulo-Squamous Eruption

 

Option B: Non-Scarring Papulo-Squamous Eruption

 

Subacute Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus presents most commonly as a Non-Scarring Papulo-Squamous Eruption. It can also present as annular polycyclic lesions.

 

Sites of lesions:

 

  • Above the Waist
  • Around the Neck
  • On the Trunk
  • Outer Aspects of the Arms

 

In this subgroup, Antibodies to the Ro (SS-A) Antigen are almost always present.

 

Its primarily a Cutaneous Disease and generally has a favourable Prognosis.

 

The image below shows Psoriasiform Lesions of Subacute Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scarring papulosquamous eruption:

 

  • While cutaneous lesions in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can sometimes scar, particularly in the case of discoid lupus, SCLE typically presents with non-scarring lesions.

 

Option C. Annular polycyclic lesions:

  • This option is not the most common presentation, making it incorrect for the purpose of this question.
  • Although annular polycyclic lesions are characteristic of SCLE, they occur in a smaller proportion of patients (about one-third) compared to the papulosquamous eruption.

 

Option D. Vesiculobullous lesions:

 

  • Vesiculobullous lesions are not typically seen in SCLE.
  • These types of lesions are more commonly associated with other dermatological conditions like bullous pemphigoid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cutaneous presentation of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (SCLE) is a non-scarring papulosquamous eruption, which is seen in the majority of patients, while a smaller percentage presents with annular polycyclic lesions.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition, Chapter 51, Page no 51.11-13

choices.text: Photosensitivity is the most common Cutaneous Manifestation
Salmon Rash is seen in this condition
Anti-Smith (anti-Sm) Antibodies are considered to be most specific for SLE
Anti-ds DNA correlates with Disease Activity

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding SLE except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Salmon Rash is seen in this condition

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Salmon rash is seen in this condition

 

Salmon rash is seen in adult-onset of Still's disease, not SLE.

 

The most common cutaneous manifestation of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus is photosensitivity.

 

In decreasing order, the cutaneous manifestations in SLE are:

 

1. Photosensitivity (Option A)

2. Raynaud's phenomenon

3. Malar rash

4. Chronic urticaria >36 hrs

5. Non-scarring alopecia

6. Painless ulcers over palate

 

SLE is more prevalent in women (7:1 to 15:1). It is connected to the classic erythematous rash known as malar/butterfly rash, which typically spares the nasolabial folds.

 

There may also be discoid rashes that resemble discoid lupus erythematosus.

 

Malar / Butterfly Rash.

 

 

Some important points regarding Antibodies in SLE:

 

  • Anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies (Option C): Most specific for SLE & included in ACR criteria. (Its levels do NOT correlate with disease activity)
  • ANA antibodies: Most sensitive antibodies.
  • Rim pattern of ANA positivity is specific for SLE.
  • Anti-ds DNA (Option D) levels correlates with disease activity.
  • Anti-Ro antibodies are associated with photosensitivity.

 

Glomerular Capillary Loops appearing as circumferentially thickened "Wire Loop" lesion, is classically seen in class IV or diffuse proliferative Lupus Nephritis.

 

Adult-Onset of Still's Disease, is a rare systemic inflammatory disease characterized by the classic triad of:

 

  1. Persistent high Spiking Fever
  2. Joint Pain
  3. Salmon Rash (Option B)

 

Educational Objective:

 

 'Salmon Rash' is not a feature of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) but is seen in adult-onset Still's disease, while SLE commonly presents with photosensitivity and may show specific antibodies like Anti-Sm and Anti-dsDNA, which correlates with disease activity.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition, Chapter 51 Page no 51.15, 51.21, 51.34

Rash Resolves over few months with Scarring
Phototherapy can be safely given to this Neonate
The most common Cutaneous finding is Raccoon Sign

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The most common Cutaneous finding is Raccoon Sign

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. The most common Cutaneous finding is raccoon sign

 

An erythematous, slightly scaly eruption on the face and periorbital skin (also known as the "Raccoon Sign," "Owl Eye," or "Eye Mask") is the most typical symptom of Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus (NLE).

 

Neonatal Lupus Erythematosus (NLE):

 

  • NLE is a well-known subtype of lupus erythematosus that is thought to be brought on by maternal antibodies crossing the placenta.
  • Skin lesions and congenital heart block (CHB) are the most common clinical manifestations.
  • Skin lesions, which may be present at birth or develop in the first few weeks of life, are present in about 50% of new-borns (NOT 10%). (Option A)
  • UV exposure may make the eruption worse (So Phototherapy, if needed, has to be administered with Caution).
    (Option C)
  • The rash gets better over the first few months of life and usually goes away without leaving any scars by the age of twelve months. Skin conditions are frequently minor and do not need to be treated. (Option B)

 

The image given below shows typical raccoon eyelid lesions in neonatal lupus erythematosus.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neonatal lupus erythematosus, the most common cutaneous manifestation is the 'raccoon sign', presenting as erythematous, slightly scaly lesions on the face and periorbital skin, which typically resolve without scarring.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition, Chapter 51, Page no’s 51.37 and 51.38

choices.text: Erythema Multiforme (EMF) is the Diagnosis
Erythema Multiforme Minor is the most common form
The Distribution of Target Lesions is mainly over Acral Sites
NSAIDs are the most common Triggering Factor for EMF

questions.text: All of the following are correct about the below given condition except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) NSAIDs are the most common Triggering Factor for EMF

 

Option D:

 

The given image shows characteristic target lesions of Erythema Multiforme (EMF) (Option A), (which most commonly occurs following a herpes simplex virus infection (NOT due to drugs)

 

Erythema Multiforme: Self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from Delayed type of hypersensitivity. It most commonly occurs following an Infection>> drug intake.

 

Clinical Features: Classic acral iris or 'target lesions'.

 

 

  • Lesions are distributed preferentially on the distal extremities (Option C). Oral and genital mucosal membranes lesions are associated with erosions.
  • The lesions appear in successive crops for a few days and fade in 1-2 weeks, sometimes leaving dusky discoloration.

 

The common triggers are:

 

  • Herpes simplex infection (Most Common) (Option D)
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy- carcinoma, lymphoma, leukaemia
  • Drugs- sulphonamides, rifampicin, penicillin’s, hydantoin derivatives
  • Miscellaneous- lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), sarcoidosis, polyarteritis nodosa

 

Explanation:

 

Option B:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythema Multiforme is often triggered by infections, particularly herpes simplex virus, rather than NSAIDs, and it commonly presents as Erythema Multiforme minor with target lesions concentrated on acral sites.

 

Refs: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 47, Page no 47.1-5

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient with neurocysticercosis develops generalised peeling of skin except palms & soles & severe oral & genital involvement starting after taking seizure medication. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis

 

Option B: Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis

 

Stevens-Johnson syndrome and Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN) are Acute life threatening severe mucocutaneous adverse drug reactions, usually to drugs, characterized by blistering and epithelial sloughing.

 

Drugs that can cause SJS/TEN are:

 

  • Allopurinol
  • NSAIDs- Oxicam group
  • Anti-Epileptics - Phenobarbital, Phenytoin, Carbamazepine, Lamotrigine
  • Antibiotics - Penicillin’s, Cephalosporins, Sulfamethoxazole, Sulfasalazine, Nevirapine.

 

The two terms Stevens Johnson Syndrome & Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis describe phenotypes within a severity spectrum.

 

Depending upon BSA involved we can see 3 possibilities as given below.

 

 

Stevens Johnson Syndrome & Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis can be associated with Conjunctivitis, Cheilitis.

 

Painful erosions over oral mucosa, covered by hemorrhagic crusts, which bleed on peeling can occur in these conditions as shown below:

 

 

In Lyell's syndrome / Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis, diffuse generalized epidermal detachment is seen with extensive mucosal involvement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Steven Johnson Syndrome (SJS):

 

  • SJS is a severe mucocutaneous reaction, often to medications, but it is characterized by less extensive skin detachment than TEN (less than 10% body surface area).
  • Given the "generalised peeling of skin", SJS is less likely than TEN.

 

Option C. Fixed drug eruption:

 

  • This condition typically presents with solitary or a few well-demarcated plaques that recur at the same site with re-exposure to the offending drug, which does not match the described extensive peeling and mucosal involvement.

 

Option D. Pemphigus vulgaris:

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder that involves the skin and mucous membranes, but it does not typically present with generalised skin peeling as a reaction to medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis is a severe drug reaction characterized by widespread skin peeling, including severe oral and genital mucosal involvement.

 

Refs:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition, Chapter 119 Page Nos 119.13-119.14

questions.text: A 55 -year-old woman presents with rash over her lips as shown in image below, after she had taken NSAIDs for her joint pain. She had reported that she developed the same rash in the same location 5 months ago when she took the same drugs for back pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fixed Drug Eruption

 

Option C: Fixed Drug Eruption

 

The given clinical situation suggests a diagnosis of a Fixed drug eruption. Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common forms of drug induced exanthems

 

Fixed drug eruption (FDE)

 

FDE is a drug eruption distinguished by its recurrence at the same sites on rechallenge, its short latency and benign nature, hence their site on the skin is fixed.

 

  • FDE typically presents 30 min to 8 h after drug exposure.
  • Typically, FDE presents as a sharply defined, round or oval erythematous and oedematous plaque which evolves to become dusky.
  • Violaceous and occasionally vesicular or bullous.
  • Classically hyperpigmentation occurs after lesions heal.

 

Most common cause:

 

  • NSAIDs - On Lips
  • Cotrimoxazole - On Genitals

 

Acute onset pigmentary changes after NSAID use point toward the diagnosis of FDE. NSAID's are one of the most common drugs causing FDE.

 

The majority of FDE is self-limiting with an excellent prognosis.

 

Note: The generalized bullous form of FDE should be differentiated from toxic epidermal necrolysis by prior similar history, absence of target lesions, and no involvement of mucosal surfaces.

 

The image below shows hyperpigmentation on the Lips & Glans penis developing simultaneously & healing at the same time frame.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chikungunya fever:

 

  • The nose and cheeks show signs of post-chikungunya hyperpigmentation on the Centro-facial face (so-called "chik sign").
  • After the fever has subsided, the pigmentary changes appear and could last for three to six months.
  • However, the question stem describes how pigmentary changes start to manifest after a few days.
  • Additionally, during the acute febrile phase, these patients will not experience any preceding erythema or eruption over the affected areas.

 

Option B. Post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH)

 

  • This is an acquired form of hyper melanosis that develops as a result of cutaneous injury or inflammation, such as impetigo, atopic dermatitis, or acne vulgaris.

 

Option D. Drug hypersensitivity

 

  • This is an immune-mediated reaction to a drug of which symptoms ranging from mild to severe include rash, anaphylaxis, and serum sickness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fixed drug eruption by the recurrence of a localized rash at the same site upon re-exposure to an offending drug, such as NSAIDs.

 

Refs: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Chapter 118 Page No 118.12

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 5-day history of a spreading rash. She reports that it began as a small red spot on her thigh that has expanded progressively and now measures approximately 15 cm in diameter. The lesion is not painful but feels warm to the touch. She recalls hiking in a heavily wooded area in the North-eastern United States two weeks prior. On examination, you observe a target like lesions as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythema Migrans

 

Option B: Erythema Migrans.

 

  • It is the hallmark rash associated with Lyme disease, which is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi and transmitted by Ixodes ticks.
  • The patient's history of hiking in an endemic area, along with the characteristic "bullseye" rash, supports this diagnosis.
  • Erythema migrans typically appears within 7-14 days after the tick bite and slowly expands over days to weeks.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erythema Annulare: It is characterized by ring-shaped lesions shown in the image below but lacks the Bulls eye appearance and is not associated with a history of tick exposure.

 

 

Option C. Erythema Marginatum: It is associated with rheumatic fever and presents with pink rings on the trunk and inner surfaces of the limbs as shown in the image below, not the expanding lesion described.

 

 

Option D. Erythema Multiforme: It is a hypersensitivity reaction associated with certain infections, medications, and other triggers and presents with multiple target lesions mainly involving extremities as shown in the image below.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythema Migrans is the characteristic rash of Lyme disease, typically presenting as a circular rash with central clearing following a tick bite in endemic areas.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 50.70

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 326

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the Derma OPD with complaints of a rash on the palms and trunk for the past 2 weeks. One week prior to the onset of her symptoms, she was diagnosed with a urinary tract infection, for which she was prescribed Trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole. Now, on general physical examination her BP is 120/80, temperature is 100.2 degrees F, pulse is 98/minute, and her respiration is 16/minute. On examination of her skin, maculopapular rash having a dusky center with multiple rings is noted as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Erythema Multiforme

 

Option C: Erythema Multiforme

 

  • This is the most likely diagnosis given the history of medication use (Trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole) and the description of a maculopapular rash with a dusky center and multiple rings (Multiple Target Lesions).
  • Erythema multiforme is often a hypersensitivity reaction to medications, infections, or other triggers.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Erythema Annulare: This term is less commonly used and may refer to a pattern seen in several conditions, but the description of rings with dusky centers is more typical of erythema multiforme.

 

Option B. Erythema Marginatum: This type of erythema is most often associated with rheumatic fever and is characterized by non-pruritic, pink rings on the trunk and inner aspects of the limbs, which do not fit the description provided.

 

Option D. Erythema Nodosum: Presents as tender red nodules, usually on the shins, and is not described as having multiple rings or a dusky center.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erythema multiforme is characterized by target lesions—a dusky central area surrounded by a paler ring and a dark outermost ring—and is often a reaction to certain medications or infections.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 47.11- 47.17

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 334

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of antiepileptic medication use presents with widespread bullous skin lesions with extensive denudation of skin covering over 60% of body surface area as shown in the image below, mucosal involvement, and a positive Pseudo Nikolsky sign. Laboratory investigations reveal the following abnormalities. Which of the following serological findings is most useful in assessing the prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Urea > 10 mmol/L

 

Option B:

 

Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN)

 

  • It is a severe and life-threatening condition characterized by widespread bullous skin lesions with extensive denudation, mucosal involvement, and a positive Nikolsky sign (or in this case, a "Pseudo Nikolsky’s" sign). Assessing the prognosis in TEN is crucial for clinical management.
  • The most useful serological finding for assessing the prognosis in TEN is elevated urea levels (Option B) since it indicates the presence of acute kidney injury, which is a significant predictor of a poor prognosis in this condition.

 

 

BSA = Body Surface Area

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alanine aminotransferase >40 IU/L –

 

Elevated liver enzymes may be seen in some cases due to systemic involvement, but they are not the primary indicator for assessing the prognosis in TEN.

 

Option C. Potassium > 2.5 mEq/L –

 

Elevated potassium levels can occur in TEN due to tissue damage and cell breakdown but are not as useful in assessing the prognosis compared to renal function.

 

Option D. Sodium 140 mEq/L –

 

Normal sodium levels do not provide specific information about the prognosis in TEN.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elevated urea levels (>10 mmol/L) are a valuable serological finding for assessing the prognosis in toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) because they indicate the presence of acute kidney injury, a significant predictor of poor outcomes in this severe skin condition.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 119.3- 119.20

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page No 341

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with severe bullous skin lesions with extensive denudation of skin covering over 60% of the body surface area, mucosal involvement as shown in the image below, and a positive Pseudo Nikolsky sign. On further evaluation, a thorough medication history reveals recent use of antibiotics for gastrointestinal complaints. What is the most likely aetiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug Induced.

 

Option C: Drug induced –

 

  • Drug-induced reactions, especially adverse drug reactions, are the most common cause of TEN. Given the recent use of antibiotics and the characteristic clinical presentation, drug induced TEN is the most likely aetiology in this case.

 

Medications Most Frequently Associated with Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) and Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN)

 

 

Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is a severe and potentially life-threatening condition characterized by widespread bullous skin lesions, mucosal involvement, and a positive Pseudo Nikolsky sign. Identifying the underlying cause is crucial for proper management.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A) Bacterial Infection –

 

  • Bacterial infections can cause skin conditions, but they are not the primary cause of TEN.
  • TEN is typically associated with medications and, less commonly, viral infections.

 

Option B) Viral Infection –

 

  • Although viral infections can lead to various skin manifestations, they are not the primary cause of TEN.
  • Medications and drug-induced reactions, such as antibiotics, are more common triggers.

 

Option D) Idiopathic –

 

  • Idiopathic means the cause is unknown, but in the majority of TEN cases, a specific trigger can be identified, such as medication use or, less commonly, viral infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN) is most commonly drug-induced, often triggered by medications like antibiotics.
  • Identifying the causative drug is crucial for management and preventing further exposure.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 119.3- 119.20

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page No 341

Associated with Sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s Phenomenon
The Dermis is 3-4 times thicker than normal

questions.text: Which of the following statements is False regarding Scleredema?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Associated with Sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s Phenomenon.

 

Option B:

 

Sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s Phenomenon are associated with Scleroderma (NOT with scleredema).

 

Scleredema & Scleroderma are different diseases.

 

 

Scleredema is not associated with sclerodactyly, Raynaud’s phenomenon, nail fold capillary changes or serum autoantibodies.

 

Scleredema:

 

Synonyms - Scleredema adultorum of Buschke, Scleredema Diabeticorum.

  • Scleredema results in taut skin with noticeable symmetrical, diffuse progressive, non-pitting induration. This is because the dermis has expanded, mucin has been deposited, and the subcutaneous fat has been replaced by coarse collagen fibers.
  • It commonly presents with erythema and induration on the posterior neck and back, along with a peaud'orange appearance of the skin. Interestingly, the hands and feet remain unaffected.
  • The condition is characterized by a 3-4 times thicker dermis than usual, caused by dysfunctional fibroblasts leading to increased type 1 collagen synthesis, but without fibroblast proliferation.
  • The most prevalent type of this condition is associated with diabetes mellitus, and it is more commonly found in men compared to other forms that are more frequently seen in women. The accumulation of collagen is attributed to irreversible glycosylation of collagen and its resistance to degradation by collagenase.

 

 

  • Against an erythematous backdrop, the image depicts scleredema in a diabetic patient with firm, non-pitting edema with induration on the upper back, neck, and shoulders.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scleredema, a connective tissue disorder associated with diabetes and characterized by dermal thickening, does not typically present with sclerodactyly and Raynaud’s phenomenon, which are features of systemic sclerosis.

 

Ref: Bolognia 4th Edition, Chapter 46, Page No 870

Rooks’ Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 59 Page No 59.09 - 59.11.

questions.text: Match the following Drugs in Column A with the Colour of pigmentation associated in Column B?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d

 

Explanation:

 

 

1. Arsenic exposure can lead to raindrop pigmentation of the skin, which presents as Small Areas of Hyperpigmentation resembling Raindrops.

 

2. Minocycline, a tetracycline antibiotic, can cause blue-black pigmentation in Acne Scars, on the Face, and in areas of previous Inflammation.

 

 

3. Chlorpromazine, an Antipsychotic medication, can lead to Blue-Grey Pigmentation typically occurring after prolonged use.

 

4. Clofazimine, used to treat Leprosy, is known to cause Brown Pigmentation of the Skin.

 

 

Drug-Induced Pigmentation

 

 

Systemic causes of hyperpigmentation

 

  • Cushing Disease, Addisons, Grave's Disease
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Megaloblastic Anemia
  • Pernicious Anemia
  • Pregnancy
  • Renal Failure
  • Systemic Sclerosis

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical recognition of drug-induced skin pigmentation requires matching the characteristic color change with the causative agent: Arsenic causes raindrop pigmentation; Minocycline leads to blue-black pigmentation; Chlorpromazine results in blue-grey pigmentation; and Clofazimine causes brown pigmentation.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page no 88.17, 88.25

choices.text: Lifting the Scale Reveals Spikes on Under Surface
Pinpoint Bleeding is visible on Removal of Scales
Scratching the Lesion will make the Scales more Apparent
Stretching the Skin, Scales tend to Fold along the Line of Stretch

questions.text: A 37-year-old female presented with lesions on face and concha as shown in the pictures below. The lesions are associated with scaling and are non-pruritic. Which of the following is a characteristic finding in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lifting the Scale Reveals Spikes on Under Surface.

 

Option A. The clinical description and image are consistent with Discoid Lupus Erythematosus (DLE), a chronic form of cutaneous lupus. The characteristic finding in DLE is the presence of "carpet tack" spikes on the under surface of the scales, which are remnants of follicular plugs.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pinpoint bleeding is visible on removal of scales:

 

Pinpoint bleeding upon removal of scales, known as the Auspitz sign, is typically seen in psoriasis when the thin layers overlying the dilated dermal papillae are removed

 

 

Option C. Scratching the lesion will make the scales more apparent:

 

  • The grattage test, where scratching a psoriatic lesion leads to more prominent scales, is suggestive of psoriasis, not DLE.

 

Option D. Stretching the skin, scales tend to fold along the line of stretch:

 

  • The collarette scale, which is a fine scale that seems to fold along the line of stretch, is characteristic of pityriasis rosea, not DLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Discoid Lupus Erythematosus, lifting the scale reveals spikes on the undersurface, which are the remnants of follicular plugs, distinguishing this condition from psoriasis and pityriasis rosea which have different characteristic scale findings.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 51.5

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page No 1166

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of a widespread rash that has been worsening over the past month. She notes that the rash gets more pronounced when she spends time in the sun. Physical examination reveals multiple annular, erythematous plaques with central clearing and slight scale, distributed over her chest and back as shown below. She denies any joint pain or systemic symptoms. Laboratory tests are ordered, and her serological studies are pending. Which of the following antibodies is most characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anti-Ro/SSA and Anti-La/SSB Antibodies:

 

Option A. Anti-Ro/SSA and Anti-La/SSB antibodies: This is the correct answer. The patient's presentation is suggestive of subacute cutaneous lupus erythematosus (SCLE), which is typically associated with Anti-Ro/SSA and Anti-La/SSB antibodies. These antibodies are also seen in Sjögren's syndrome but the rash is characteristic of SCLE.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anti-Double-Stranded DNA (dsDNA) Antibodies: Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) and are typically associated with more severe disease, including renal involvement, which is not indicated in this patient's presentation.

 

Option C. Anti-Centromere Antibodies: Anti-centromere antibodies are most commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), previously known as CREST syndrome, which does not present with the annular plaques seen in SCLE.

 

Option D. Anti-Smooth Muscle Antibodies: Anti-smooth muscle antibodies are often associated with autoimmune hepatitis, which does not present with the cutaneous findings described for this patient.

 

Antibodies and Associated Diseases in SLE and Other Conditions


 

Educational Objective:

 

In Subacute Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus (SCLE), Anti-Ro/SSA and Anti-La/SSB antibodies are characteristic serological findings, and these patients often present with photosensitive annular plaques with central clearing.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 51.13

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page No 668

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of hair loss and skin lesions. She reports that the skin lesions have been present for several months and often feel tender. She has also noticed sores in her mouth. Her medical history is significant for joint pain and fatigue. On examination, you note several round, well-defined plaques with erythema, scale, and central scarring on her scalp. The patient also has diffuse, non-scarring alopecia. No lymphadenopathy is palpable. Which of the following findings is most characteristic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Discoid Lesions:

 

Option B. Discoid lesions are a hallmark of chronic cutaneous lupus erythematosus, which can occur in the setting of SLE. These lesions are characterized by round, well-defined, erythematous plaques with scale and central scarring, particularly on the scalp, as described in this patient's presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anagen Effluvium 

 

  • Anagen effluvium is a form of hair loss that occurs during the anagen or growth phase of the hair cycle, usually due to chemotherapy.
  • This is not a characteristic finding in SLE.

 

Option C. Painful Oral Ulcers:

 

  • Oral ulcers in SLE are painless, which helps differentiate them from other types of ulcers.

 

 

  • While painful oral ulcers can occur in SLE, they are not as specific or characteristic as discoid lesions.

 

Option D. Raccoon Eyes:

 

  • Raccoon eyes, or bilateral periorbital ecchymosis, are typically associated with Neonatal SLE, basal skull fractures or certain types of amyloidosis, not in adult forms of SLE.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Discoid lesions is characteristic cutaneous manifestations of SLE, which present as well-defined, erythematous plaques with scaling and central scarring on the scalp.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 51.15

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 672

choices.text: Rheumatoid Nodules - Juvenile Rheumatic Arthritis
Mechanic's Hand - Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

questions.text: The clinical finding in the 10-year-old boy includes fever, joint pain, and a hand lesion as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis based on these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Gottron's Papules - Juvenile Dermatomyositis.

 

Option A. Gottron's Papules - Juvenile Dermatomyositis:

 

  • Juvenile Dermatomyositis is a rare inflammatory disease affecting the skin and muscles. It typically presents in children with a characteristic skin rash and muscle weakness.
  • Gottron's papules are distinctive red or violet, raised, scaly lesions seen over knuckles (dorsal interphalangeal or metacarpophalangeal joints), elbows, knees, and other extensor surfaces, highly suggestive of dermatomyositis.
  • The combination of fever, joint pain, and Gottron's papules strongly indicates juvenile dermatomyositis.
  • The Gottron's sign is a distribution of symmetric, non-scaling, violaceous, erythematous macules or plaques that are frequently atrophic.

 

 

Gottron's sign seen in the above image

 

  • Shawl Sign or V-Sign: Fixed Macular Erythema spanning the Shoulders and Outer Arms (Shawl distribution) as seen in the image below

 

 

  • Periungual Telangiectasias: Enlarged Capillaries in the Nail Folds.

 

 

  • Mechanic's Hand: Roughening and Cracking of the Fingertip and Side Skin that results in Scuffed, Crooked lines that resemble those of a Mechanic or Manual Laborer.

 

 

  • Proximal myopathy: Patients have trouble performing everyday activities like climbing stairs, getting up, and lifting their arms above their heads.

 

Laboratory evaluation of patients with dermatomyositis will reveal elevated serum creatinine kinase and antinuclear antibodies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Rheumatoid Nodules - Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

  • Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis is an Autoimmune disorder causing chronic joint inflammation in children.
  • Rheumatoid Nodules are Firm, Painless, Subcutaneous nodules that usually occur in areas of pressure but are not typically seen in the hands in this form.

 

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis and rheumatoid nodules. Note the periarticular location of the skin- coloured nodules .
  • The lesion in the image doesn't match the typical appearance of rheumatoid nodules.

 

Option C. Sclerodactyly - Systemic Sclerosis:

 

  • Systemic Sclerosis is a connective tissue disease characterized by skin thickening and hardening (scleroderma).
  • Sclerodactyly refers to thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers and hands, leading to a claw-like appearance.
  • The lesion shown doesn't indicate the skin thickening or tightness characteristic of sclerodactyly.

 

Option D. Mechanic's Hand - Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease affecting multiple organ systems.
  • Mechanic's hand is a sign associated more with dermatomyositis than SLE, characterized by rough, cracked skin on the sides of the fingers, mimicking the hands of a manual labourer.
  • The presentation of mechanic's hand in SLE is less common and the symptoms described do not align well with SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case involving fever, joint pain, and hand lesions in a child, the presence of Gottron's papules is indicative of Juvenile dermatomyositis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 53 Page no 53.1-53.12

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition Page 2820-2821

choices.text: EM Minor has Mucosal Involvement

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a rapidly developing rash. He reports a recent history of herpes simplex virus infection and has been taking a sulphonamide antibiotic for a urinary tract infection. Physical examination reveals multiple round lesions with a typical target or "iris" appearance, centrally darkened with concentric rings, located on his palms and soles. Some of the lesions are also noted on his trunk and face. The patient denies any respiratory or gastrointestinal symptoms. All are true about EMF except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) EM Minor has Mucosal Involvement

 

Option D:

This is the correct answer as the statement is false. EM minor typically does not involve mucosal surfaces; mucosal involvement is more characteristic of EM major or Stevens-Johnson syndrome, which represents a more severe form of the disease.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Associated with Herpes Simplex: Erythema Multiforme (EM) is frequently associated with herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections. HSV is one of the most common precipitating factors for EM.

 

Option B. Associated with Sulphonamides: EM can be associated with reactions to certain medications, including sulphonamides, which are known to be a common drug trigger.

 

Option C. Lesions are Symmetrical: The lesions in EM are typically symmetrical and often present with a classic target or iris appearance, as described in the vignette.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Erythema multiforme minor is characterized by target lesions without mucosal involvement, unlike erythema multiforme major, which does include mucosal lesions.
  • EM can be triggered by infections such as Herpes Simplex Virus and medications like Sulphonamides and the lesions are typically symmetrical.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 47, Page no 47.1-5

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th Edition Page no 323
